snippet.title: Passion for bath and body products grows from necessity
snippet.content: WHAT started out as a medical necessity has become a passion for Terry and Melek Fahey. They have turned their range of soaps into a fully fledged business to help others. With a daughter suffering from eczema and nothing on the market that appeared to help, Terry and Melek took it into their own hands to create a good, natural, chemical-free product. "We could only find things that were harsh on the skin long-term," Melek said. "They were masking the problem and not fixing it." Through extensive research and years of trial and error, they finally created a product using coconut milk and goats milk, as they are both nourishing, moisturising and soothing for the skin. The Faheys soon had soap overflowing their home, so they decided to trial the product at market stalls, leading to the birth of their business Oska and Willow - Artisan Bath and Body. Now with a full studio at their home, they are regulars at markets around the region and soon able to supply direct to customers online. The couple soon realised customers wanted more natural product lines, so they expanded their range, introducing their body and bath products which included hand and body wash, lip balms, bath bombs, bath milks, essential oil room sprays and organic hand-rolled beeswax candles. Now a new range released shortly will consist of body lotions, coffee body scrubs and even their own range of organic perfumes. Terry and Melek use the traditional cold-process method to create their soap, colouring each batch individually to match the fragrance, ensuring that each bar is unique. "After five years, I realised it didn't have to look boring, it could be pretty, too, so I used it as my form of art," Melek said. "I love it. I will smell a fragrance and the design will come to me." Oska and Willow is a business that tries to use as many locally sourced products as possible, allowing Terry and Melek to give back to the community. "It highlights what's available in our region," Melek said. "We are supporting the community and other companies - keeping each other strong." Their ultimate goal is to open their own shopfront within the Sunshine Coast, allowing them to consistently engage with customers throughout the week, creating a more personalised experience.
